vulnerability_information:
Hello,

I found another bug on hackerone.
This time it is very dangerous and creative.
Hope you will definitely love it.

Any valid account on hackerone can be hacked. eg Co-founders @jobert and @michiel can also be hacked.
I tried this one on my account only.

Lets go to the point ...

Things required to takeover complete account :
========================================
1. Valid email-id which is registered on hackerone.

Now, chaining from my previously i.e lately reported bugs.
User enumeration attack I reported recently.

One can find a registered email easily. eg michiel@hackerone.com or jobert@hackerone.com

Basic Idea :
==========
1. I am requesting a 'Reset Password link' to user's email. 
eg.
https://hackerone.com/users/password/edit?reset_password_token=MUm2xQ_TEtf2RaG1H3DK

2. Guessing the reset_password_token i.e reset_password_token=MUm2xQ_TEtf2RaG1H3DK

As everyone replying my bug reports know that there is no BRUTE FORCE protection. I am doing the same.


Proof of concept :
================
1. Generate a 'Reset Password link' of user whose account is to be compromised/hacked.
2. Use a burp suite and configure it to do a Brute Force Attack on token
eg. https://hackerone.com/users/password/edit?reset_password_token=MUm2xQ_TEtf2RaG1H3DK

Now, it is very easy to identify valid reset_password_tokens.

Server Status 200 ---> valid
Server Status 302 ----> invalid

length 4378 --->valid
length 1525 --->invalid

3. Try resetting password now.
4. Login with email and password.

Special Note :
===========
Attacker doing a brute force will get all valid tokens which are requested by user and are valid.
So attacker can reset password of users.

This was all from me. Hope now you understand the severity and power of Brute Force.
I am attaching a screenshot POC to show that there is no protection from server side as mentioned by @michiel and @jobert to me recently about brute force.

Just I made attack on my account. To show it I am attaching a screen shot. 
And there is really no protection from hackerone server. I have already made few thousands request and I am eagerly waiting for something to block me from server side.

Hope you quickly get back to me. :)

Regards,
Pranav

activities.message: Hi @pranav_hivarekar - is this quick enough? ;-) Thanks for your report. The problem with brute forcing these kind of tokens is that it is not very likely you'll actually hit an unused password reset token. The password reset tokens expire after 6 hours and cannot be guessed easily (as far as I know, the tokens are not predictable). Also, we have a number of systems monitoring for unusual amount of traffic to our app servers (but you knew that already :)). Just to make sure: did you find a way to predict the tokens besides brute force? Thanks!
Oh, and in case you requested the password reset for my account a couple minutes ago: please use a test account you own next time.

When password token is valid. Attacker can get it.
I am doing requests from 30 min ago still nothing is blocking me from making requests. I want you to emphasize this 
"Also, we have a number of systems monitoring for unusual amount of traffic to our app servers (but you knew that already :)). "

I agree I did not knew about expiration time. ;)
I know the hash is 20 letters long and requires about 2,14,74,83,647 guesses. This may take several days.

But why aren't any measures against Brute Force are implemented on hackerone?

What about creating a fake account and guessing the confirmation token? i.e confirmation_token=BQboHuTtwVmMsy8VbKR2
eg. https://hackerone.com/users/confirmation?confirmation_token=BQboHuTtwVmMsy8VbKR2

And one more attack I want to discuss @jobert.

Spamming any user after finding his email-id.

As everyone knows hackerone has no protection against brute force.

SO basically,

1. I may create a file entering email-id as jobert@hackerone.com some few thousand times ;) eg consider 25000
2. Do a brute force on Reset Password page loading the file.

This also can be done through a script. But I mentioned simplest attack.

This will send you @jobert 25000 mails. This will be irritating for you the most.
Hope now you understand what I am pointing too.

Please reply me point by point.

> When password token is valid. Attacker can get it.

Theoretically, yes. But, because of the 6 hour time window, it's not a realistic attack scenario.

> I know the hash is 20 letters long and requires about 2,14,74,83,647 guesses. This may take several days.

Brute forcing a password reset token will take years, not several days. Looking at the time window a password reset token is valid, this is (again) not realistic. If you like, check out [this code](https://github.com/plataformatec/devise/blob/d56641f514f54da04f778b2a9b816561df7910c2/lib/devise/token_generator.rb). That's the class we use for generating password reset and confirmation tokens.

> But why aren't any measures against Brute Force are implemented on hackerone?

Because none of the attacks are realistic. In theory they would work, but so far we have never seen a realistic attack scenario regarding tokens we use (password reset, confirmations, invitations).

> What about creating a fake account and guessing the confirmation token? 

The only theoretical impact is that you can confirm a user account that has an email address you don't actually own. I don't see any other implications and doubt that it's an actual security bug. Am I missing something?

> How can you say I requested a password Reset link for your account?

Please read my comment again, because I didn't say that. I never had someone else request a password reset for my account. Since you mentioned it in your initial submission, it's possible you triggered it (even by accident). Just making sure we're at the same page about the rules of our bug bounty program.

> Recently, I reported 'User Enumeration' attack. @michiel attended that report and finally declined.
> 
> Few days back, I reported the same bug (User Enumeration ) on FACEBOOK. And now today I got listed in Facebook White hat. You can check my name on https://www.facebook.com/whitehat/thanks/

Congratulations on your listing on the Facebook Whitehat Hall of Fame!

> I know I reported few theoretical reports, because I believe that hackerone should be as secure as others.

I partially agree with you here. Yes, we should be as secure as possible, but the impact of a security vulnerability can vary based upon a combination of:

- The type of user that's being targeted
- The impact of the vulnerability

This can make it that we as HackerOne, decide not to fix certain reports that other companies might have fixed.
 
> As I can find a valid email-id which is registered on hackerone and request as many links I want.
> Here, user's email inbox will be spammed. 
> You would not like to lose a User or A Team which is registered on hackerone due to spamming.

I personally don't think that we will lose users, in case this ever happens. Our users know that we're a security oriented site, and although we really don't like to bother our users with stuff like this, I think that they will have enough understanding of the situation to not leave our site. Even more so because we would ban the spammer as soon as we'd detect an attack.

> I know you will now understand the severity of this bug. I want you to fix this bug on 'Reset Password Page'.

We still consider this bug a won't fix. I hope that I was able to convince you of our stance on this matter. I think that some of these low-priority bugs might get fixed in a more distant future, but for now we're focussing on getting the product even more awesome ;-). I hope you understand.

> I hope you will understand what I wanted to say this time.

Thanks for the excellent explanation! It really helped me understand the point that you're trying to make. Though I would like to ask you if you could file separate bugs for things like these. Your original report was called "Account takeover", but it turned into "Ability to spam members of HackerOne", which is a totally different report in my opinion. You maybe could've even replied on the already closed "User Enumeration" report.

We handle all reports with care, so there is no need to worry that we won't reply to you if you create another report for another bug!

Thanks again for the explanation, and thanks for the effort you put in helping us improve our security!

Remon
